title: About
text:
My name is James S. Norcross and I am currently a final year Doctoral Candidate in the Public and Nonprofit Management program in the field of Public Affairs at the University of Texas at Dallas. I am also a full-time faculty in the Department of Cybersecurity in the School of ETMS at Dallas College. I teach courses in Cybersecurity, Computer Information Systems, and the use of AI/ML in these fields. Upon completing my PhD, it is my intent to seek a position with a university in the Northeast region of the United States to be closer to family and to have a chance of seeing snow in the winter season. This webpage was developed to show my work and as part of my ongoing studies in the field of Data Science for Social Sciences. If you wish to contact me regarding any of my material on this webpage or my future career plans, please feel free to connect with me at:
Email: James.Norcross@UTDallas.edu

title: James S. Norcross
text:
James S. Norcross
Welcome to my website!
I am a final year doctoral candidate at the University of Texas at Dallas in the Public and Nonprofit Management program in the School of Economics, Politics, and Policy Sciences. My research foci are Cybersecurity and Information Systems in local government and nonprofit organizations. I also serve as a faculty member in the Department of Cybersecurity in the School of ETMS at Dallas College, in which I teach courses in Cybersecurity, Computer Information Systems and Artificial Intelligence.
Contact Information:
James.Norcross@UTDallas.edu

title: Research
text:
My area of research is Cybersecurity and Information Systems, particularly as applied local governments and nonprofit organizations. As there is a limited amount of research in this area of inquiry in the general field of Public Affairs, there are numerous conceptual areas I’m investigating; some of these areas are:

Local government spending and budget allocation following a cyber-attack.
Evaluating cyber-threats focused on local governments and nonprofit organizations.
The role of capital investment spending in supporting local governments’ financial recovery from a cyber-attack.
Investigating current research in fields outside of Public Affairs that may be used to develop cybersecurity management strategies to improve local government and nonprofit cybersecurity resiliency.

title: EPPS 6356
text:
R Programming Basic Commands
Create object using the assignment operator (<-, =)
’’’{r}
Basic Commands
Create object using the assignment operator (<-, =)
{r} x <- c(1,3,2,5) x x = c(1,6,2) x y = c(1,4,3)
Using function
{r} length(x) # What does length() do? length(y)
Using +, -, *, /,^ operators
{r} x+y ls() # List objects in the environment rm(x,y) # Remove objects ls() rm(list=ls()) # Danger! What does this do? Not recommended!
Matrix operations
{r} ?matrix x=matrix(data=c(1,2,3,4), nrow=2, ncol=2) # Create a 2x2 matrix object x x=matrix(c(1,2,3,4),2,2) matrix(c(1,2,3,4),2,2,byrow=TRUE) # What about byrow=F?
sqrt(x) # What does x look like?
x^2
x=rnorm(50) # Generate a vector of 50 numbers using the rnorm() function
y=x+rnorm(50,mean=50,sd=.1) # What does rnorm(50,mean=50,sd=.1) generate?
cor(x,y) # Correlation of x and y set.seed(1303) # Set the seed for Random Number Generator (RNG) to generate values that are reproducible. rnorm(50) set.seed(3) # Try different seeds? y=rnorm(100)
Simple descriptive statistics
{r} mean(y) var(y) sqrt(var(y)) sd(y)
Graphics using R Graphics (without packages)
{r}
x=rnorm(100) y=rnorm(100) plot(x,y, pch=20, col = “blue”) # Scatterplot for two numeric variables by default plot(x,y, pch=20, col = “blue”,xlab=“this is the x-axis”,ylab=“this is the y-axis”,main=“Plot of X vs Y”) # Add labels pdf(“Figure01.pdf”) # Save as pdf, add a path or it will be stored on the project directory plot(x,y,pch=20, col=“forestgreen”) # Try different colors? dev.off() # Close the file using the dev.off function x=seq(1,10) # Same as x=c(1:10) x x=1:10 x x=seq(-pi,pi,length=50) y=x

title: EPPS 6356
text:
R Programming Basic Commands
```{r} # Create object using the assignment operator x <- c(1,3,2,5) x x = c(1,6,2) x y = c(1,4,3)
# Using function length(x) # What does length() do? length(y)
# Using +, -, *, /, ^ operators x + y ls() # List objects in the environment rm(x, y) # Remove objects ls() rm(list = ls()) # Danger! What does this do? Not recommended!
# Matrix operations x = matrix(data = c(1,2,3,4), nrow = 2, ncol = 2) # Create a 2x2 matrix object x x = matrix(c(1,2,3,4), 2, 2) matrix(c(1,2,3,4), 2, 2, byrow = TRUE) # What about byrow=F?
# Square root and power of matrix sqrt(x) x^2
# Generate random normal values x = rnorm(50) # Generate a vector of 50 numbers using the rnorm() function y = x + rnorm(50, mean = 50, sd = .1) # What does rnorm(50, mean=50, sd=.1) generate?
